thread.title: Parents say disabled children left with nowhere to turn after high school
thread.title_full: Parents say disabled children left with nowhere to turn after high school

author: Laura Dooney
title: Parents say disabled children left with nowhere to turn after high school
text:
Parents say disabled children left with nowhere to turn after high school LAURA DOONEY Last updated 20:40, February 13 2017 ROSS GIBLIN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Elaine Gousmett and her daughter Chardonnay Kyle, 16 have found how difficult it is for kids with special needs to transfer from high school to further learning, or employment. 
Parents of children with special needs say their kids are facing a "big black hole" in making the transition from high school to employment or further education. 
Some are choosing to keep their children at school until they are 21, and are frustrated by a lack of communication between services designed to cater for their children, and schools. 
Advocates say secondary schools are not doing enough planning to help students with disabilities or special needs prepare for the outside world. ROSS GIBLIN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Jo and her daughter Amanda. Jo says there needs to be better communication between services and agencies to help in the transition from high school. 
Mark Shanks has worked with families in the Hutt Valley as a project manager for Life Unlimited, a charitable trust which provides information and support to people with disabilities. He says there is not enough long-term planning at schools for students with special needs.

"I think it sits with secondary schools. Once they [students] start ... they should have a plan beginning then for when that student's going to leave." 
Schools should have individual education plans for special needs students, and those plans should sit alongside, or morph into, an individual transition plan. 
There needed to be better collaboration with agencies, as parents weren't always aware of what was available in the community. 
"Often what happens is a child leaves school and they haven't done the work in time, nothing's there and suddenly parents and the young person are going 'what's next?', they have no idea what they're doing." 
Elaine Gousmett's 16-year-old daughter, Chardonnay Kyle, finished school last year. She has spina bifida, ADD, dyspraxia and a mild intellectual impairment. 
The Upper Hutt mother believed if school was not helping her child advance to the next level, there was no point staying. When Gousmett asked what options her daughter had after school, she was told there was nothing. 
"There is just a big black hole." 
Parents whose children were eligible kept them at school until they were 21 "because there was nothing else in the world for them to do". 
Another Upper Hutt parent, who would only be identified as Jo, said she faced an uphill battle finding a place for 22-year-old Amanda after she finished school last year. 
Amanda has Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, epilepsy characterised by learning impairments. 
The pair had meetings with staff from the Ministry of Education and the school, but people "did not have a lot of answers". 
"It all seemed to be up to me." 
Her daughter was now enrolled in a "fantastic" service, but it had been hard to organise. 
However, Secondary Principals' Association president Sandy Pasley said that when special needs were identified, schools had individual education plans for those students, and met with parents regularly to look to the future. 
These included working out what the students' needs would be for literacy and numeracy, and making sure the school had a programme that targeted them into future employment where possible. 
Katrina Casey, deputy secretary Sector Enablement and Support at the Ministry of Education, said every school had systems in place to help young people make the transition. 
School staff worked closely with other agencies so families had all the information they needed. 
The ministry was leading work to improve transitions from school and tertiary education into employment. The project would ensure the ministry started working with families when they were 14. - Stuff
